testimony: I call N J Vermeulen, Mr Chairman.
N J Vermeulen.  Please switch on and then please give your full names for the record.
Thank you, please sit.  Mr Cornelius?

Thank you, Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Vermeulen, handed in a proper application for amnesty in accordance with Section 18 of the Act, is this correct?
At the time of these events you were an employee as defined in Section 20(2)(a) and 20(2)(f) of the Act of Reconciliation, is that correct?
You were then affiliated to the unit which was known as Vlakplaas, Section C1, and as appears from the additional bundles and also the activities of Vlakplaas.
At the time of this incident I understand that you were a Warrant Officer.
You confirm the contents of your amnesty application?
Mr Cornelius, just a moment.  Whoever else is in possession of one of those things, won't you just switch it off.  Sorry, Mr Cornelius.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	You at all times acted strictly within the mandate of your commander, Col de Kock.
Just to make it clear, your application for amnesty at this stage is for the illegal possession of a firearm, an AK47, is this correct?
You have not applied for conspiracy to murder or something to that effect?
You at all times acted within the scope of your duty.
Can you please shortly tell us what happened, you received orders to accompany the Vlakplaas unit to Natal, on the request of the Durban Security unit.
Did you have any knowledge of the aim of this request?
Could you please tell the Committee.

At the time of this request Durban was reasonably active and there were several Security Police officers who had already been killed and a request was lodged that the Vlakplaas unit should go to Durban branch to help to try and find the people who had killed the police officers.
Was any instruction given to you at that stage or even later that you had to come and kill the people?
Good.  If we look at your application on page 75 and in the first paragraph you say that you had already been busy working at Vlakplaas, is this correct?
Good.  Who accompanied you to the CR Swart Police Station, can you remember this?
We drove in a group, it was Willie Nortje, myself, Steve Bosch and Frank McCarter.
Did you receive certain instructions to infiltrate the area?
Could you please tell us what happened that specific evening.
Are you talking about the Chesterville incident?
That specific evening we deployed in a group.
Can you please tell us who "we" were?

It was myself and Willie and Frank McCarter and Steve Bosch, these were the white people, and all the black people.  I cannot remember them by name, but Simon Radebe and Aubrey and Shosha were some of the members that I can remember, Mr Chairperson.
The other members, if you put it this way, were actually the askaris, is this not so?

We then drove to a police station or an army base, I'm not completely sure anymore, where a certain army officer then pointed out to us that Chesterville had been a flashpoint and that we could try to infiltrate there.
It has already been put that Willie Nortje and the other three white members had gone to the station, is this correct?
The askaris apparently did not go along.
And then you returned to the group, what happened then?
We instructed them there, Willie instructed them that they had to go into the Chesterville area and that they had to try and gain information or try and contact the so-called comrades or SDU units.
In other words you should infiltrate, identify and report back.
We waited at a graveyard if I can remember it correctly.
And this group of askaris, did they report back to you?
They went back and they came back with the request that they want a showpiece as a weapon, and Willie at that stage had given them an AK47 as a result of their request.

I refer you to paragraph 2 of your amnesty application on page 75, and there's another typographical error
"East block weapons were given to give the ANC members reason."
This is then the showpiece.
This is then the showpiece, Chairperson.
Do you ask this to be amended?  Would you like this to be changed to a show weapon, showpiece weapon?
Did this showpiece then get handed over to Simon Radebe?
Yes, an AK was handed over by Willie Nortje.
The members then left again and if I can remember correctly we moved to a place close to a bridge and we waited there.

After a while a shooting - we heard a shooting.  Simon returned to us and said that a shooting had taken place.  Myself and Willie and the white people got into the vehicle.  I think Willie gave instructions that they had to go to CR Swart Police Station.
Was Simon Radebe on foot or was he in a vehicle?
They were in a vehicle, Chairperson.
And they drove away from the bridge in a vehicle.
Did you at that stage then report back to the Commanding Officer, de Kock?
We went back to CR Swart where we found Col de Kock in his sleeping quarters and he was busy sleeping and Willie then reported this incident to him, Mr Chairperson.
When Simon Radebe reported to you, what were your impressions, that the situation had gotten out of hand or what had happened?
He did not report the incident to me personally, he reported it to Willie Nortje and he said that a shooting had taken place and that people had been killed, Mr Chairperson.
Did he indicate that they acted in self-defence or not?
The feeling that I got was that they had been shot on and that they returned fire.
You heard the evidence of Nofomela who gave evidence this morning, that he was at the scene by the bridge, do you have any comment on this?
I cannot remember his presence there, Mr Chairperson.
Was Col de Kock at the bridge?
No, he was not there at all.
And Simon and the askaris also did not go into Chesterville on foot.
Did you ever make a statement about this incident to the police?
Did you at any stage give evidence at an inquiry?
Had there at all in your presence been planning beforehand that people would be murdered that specific evening?
You also never received an order to this effect?
Did you expect that people would be shot dead that evening?
Where did you think that this AK47 came from?
As far as I knew, the AK had been received from Security Headquarters' safe and this is how it arrived at Willie, Mr Chairperson.
You at some stage also thought that the weapon could possibly have come from Vlakplaas itself.
The people who had been acted against as far as the infiltration is concerned, were they originally ANC or what political affiliation did they have?
According to my knowledge they were from the ANC, Mr Chairperson.
Was the whole action launched and the whole operation by C10, against the so-called enemy, was it aimed at infiltrating the so-called enemy?
Had it also been your thought?
And you then apply for amnesty - or let me just be complete.  You did not receive any reward?
You also did not expect a reward?
You did not have any ill will or malice against these members that were attacked that evening?
You accordingly apply for amnesty for the possible illegal possession of a firearm.
Just to be complete, although you had knowledge of the weapon, who handed the weapon to Simon Radebe?
And at the stage when Steve Bosch - let me rather ask you this.  Which four white people had there been?
It was myself, McCarter, Steve Bosch and Willie Nortje, Sir.
At the stage when you were waiting at the bridge, was Vermeulen present?

Thank you, Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR CORNELIUS
Thank you, Mr Cornelius.  Mr Ramawele, questions?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	Mr Vermeulen, tell me, I heard that you - in your testimony there is nowhere where Mr de Kock features in this Chesterville incident.
What was your rank at the time when this incident occurred?
You were working under the direct instruction of Mr de Kock, is that not so?
At Vlakplaas and also in Durban you were under the command of Mr de Kock.
Do you know with whom Mr de Kock went to Durban?
So you only saw Mr de Kock after he had arrived in Durban?
You cannot dispute the fact that - you cannot dispute the evidence of Mr Nofomela that he went with Mr de Kock to Durban therefore?
Now in Durban the discussion relating to the infiltration, who gave the members the instruction to go and make the infiltration?
I do not understand the question.  Was this with the Chesterville incident or in general?
I'm talking about the Chesterville incident, Mr Vermeulen.

No-one specifically gave an order that Chesterville specifically had to be the target area.  Nortje and myself as I've said, had gone to the army base where they indicated to us that Chesterville was a flashpoint and Willie Nortje decided that he would deploy the group there, Chairperson.
Where did Mr Nortje decide that?  Where was it, in Vlakplaas or in Durban?
Here in Durban itself, at the police station or the army base, Mr Chairperson.
At that time when Mr Nortje made that decision where was Mr de Kock?
Mr de Kock was at that stage - I did not see him, but I assume that he was at the quarters at CR Swart.
You are not able to say whether Mr de Kock was part of that particular decision that was taken?
Mr de Kock was not at all present at that decision to go to Chesterville, Mr Chairperson.
Mr de Kock should have known that Chesterville was a boiling point at that time, not so?
That is correct, he could have known this, Mr Chairperson.
Could he have known or should he have known?
I believe that he should have known.
And tell me, the - and also, Mr de Kock should have known that there were police officers who were killed in Durban, he should have known that.
And now when a decision is taken to infiltrate the UDF or the ANC in Chesterville, Mr de Kock is not there.
Was he asleep at that time when the decision was taken?
I cannot say, Mr Chairperson, I was not present with Mr de Kock.
Okay.  So you say Mr Nortje now made a decision that an infiltration has to be done?
And who was to make the infiltration?
The team that moved out with us, Mr Chairperson.

So you were part of the - were you part of the group that went to Durban, or let me put it this way.  Did the Vlakplaas members who went to Durban, did they come in groups or did they all, except Mr de Kock, did they all just arrive in Durban at once?
If I can remember correctly, then the whole team arrived at the same time at CR Swart, Mr Chairperson.
And who of the members were supposed to go and do the infiltration?

As far as I can remember, if this is the Chesterville incident, then it was Simon Radebe, Shosha and another black lady, I've forgotten her name, I think Aubrey Magade and other people who I can't remember immediately, Mr Chairperson.
And according to you they did make the infiltration?
They came back to report that it was successful?

No, I would not say that they returned and said that it was a success, they returned and if I can remember correctly, they said to Willie that they find it difficult to gain the people's confidence because they feel a little bit suspect and they - and he asked if there isn't a weapon of the east block origin that they can show to these people to put them more at their ease, Mr Chairperson.
Is it your evidence that the members did not report that the infiltration was a success?
Did they want the weapon to demonstrate their supposed links with the ANC?
And after that, it is then that Mr Nortje then gave the AK47 to Radebe?
Where was Mr de Kock at that time?
I would not know, Sir, but he was definitely not at the scene with us.
So again when the weapon was given to Radebe, for them to go back to the township, Mr de Kock according to you wasn't there?
It seems to me that Mr de Kock came to Durban on that particular day to come and do nothing.
I would not be able to answer this, maybe you have to ask him yourself, Mr Chairperson.

I'm saying so because he knew that the situation was volatile, police officers were killed, when a decision is taken to infiltrate he is not there, when a decision is taken again to give a weapon to some members to go back, again he's not there.  That's why I'm saying so.
I believe that you have to ask Mr de Kock that question himself, I cannot answer that, Mr Chairperson.
But Mr de Kock was truly committed to his cause of eliminating the opponents, not so?  You know it.
Now you say that they went into the - now when the weapon was given to Radebe, did you - are you saying that Radebe and the other members went into Chesterville and you also followed suit?
No, we did not follow them, Chairperson.
I see.  So Radebe actually, he went to Chesterville with the weapon?
Was he with the very same members he was when he was going to make the infiltration?
After he had gone, where did he go?
From there we moved away and we waited for them under a bridge, Mr Chairperson.
The weapon was given at the police station, at CR Swart Police Station, not so?
It was just outside Chesterville we had handed it over.
So when Mr Radebe came to say "The people do not believe us", where were you at that stage?
I was together with Mr Nortje in the vehicle that was waiting outside Chesterville, Chairperson.
No, Mr Chairperson, it was at a graveyard.
And after Mr Radebe had gone back with the firearm, where did you wait?
Then we moved, we went to a bridge and we waited for them at the bridge, Mr Chairperson.
So what you are saying is that the first time when they went to do the infiltration you were at the graveyard, when they came back you went to the bridge?
Initially why did you wait at the graveyard?
I do not know, Mr Chairperson, I was not in command of this operation, it was Willie Nortje and I also do not know that area of Chesterville.
You never asked why you were supposed to wait at the graveyard?
And later on did you know why you had to wait at the bridge?

I think that they decided that we should move, that we shouldn't be staying at the same place for too long.  This is what I assume, I don't know what the real reason is.  Mr Nortje would be able to provide this reason much better, Chairperson.
Now after - according to you, after Radebe had - if Radebe was able to successfully convince the UDF that he was a member of the ANC, what would he have done, Mr Radebe?
Mr Chairman, I don't follow the question.
Are you - pardon, what is your answer?
I do not know what he would have done, Mr Chairperson.

So you are saying the situation in Durban is volatile, police officers are killed, a police officer from Vlakplaas goes to Chesterville to infiltrate the UDF and if he succeeds you don't know what he'll do?  Is that what you're saying?
Does it make sense under those political conditions at that time?
Mr Chairperson, I was not at the scene where Mr Radebe had been, so I cannot answer on behalf of him, I cannot speculate what he would have done if he had been successful with these actions.

In other words what you are saying is that it is possible that if Mr Radebe succeeded in convincing the people that he was a member of the UDF, he could simply have come back to CR Swart and say "I succeeded", without arresting them, doing anything?
I do not know, I would not be able to answer this.

I put it to you that it is highly improbable that under those conditions, if what you are saying is the truth, that Radebe would simply just have done the infiltration.  I put it to you that that is highly improbable.

If I have to speculate then I would say that if Radebe could infiltrate there, then he would have tried to identify people, then he would have tried to obtain names and addresses, the sort of normal infiltration, and if there had been someone who would have been worth the effort, then he would have tried to arrest this person and he would have brought this person back for questioning, Chairperson, but this is merely speculation on my behalf.
And where was Geoff Bosigo at that time?
I do not know, Mr Chairperson.
Do you remember Geoff Bosigo being part of the group that waited at the bridge?
I cannot remember that Geoff Bosigo was present there, Chairperson.
Do you remember Geoff Bosigo having come to Durban at that time, during those times?
Now what were you supposed to do at the bridge?  You are waiting at the bridge, what are you supposed to do?
We were there to give support to the people if any problems arose, Mr Chairperson.
I see.  Now, are you saying if they are shot at you would have come to their assistance?

At that stage we did not know exactly where they were in the township, so it would have been difficult for us to reach them, but if a shooting had taken place as had indeed taken place, then they would have come back themselves.  If after a while they did not return we would have gone to go and look for them, Chairperson.
You did not know the township very well, is that so?
I did not know it at all, Chairperson.
You did not know where Radebe and his team were going, you did not know where they went to, not so? - precisely in Chesterville.
So in actual fact, if they got shot in Chesterville, you wouldn't have been able to go there and assist because you didn't know where they went, not so?

Therefore, when you were at the bridge you couldn't have assisted them because you didn't know were they went to and you didn't even know the place.  So there - you were sitting there doing nothing and you couldn't have assisted them.  Now tell us the real reason why were you at the bridge.

We sat there and we waited for them, Chairperson.  They went into Chesterville as I said, us white people, if one can call it that, could not go into Chesterville, it would have been very suspicious, Mr Chairperson.
But Geoff Bosigo is a black person and he never went into Chesterville.
I would not be able to say because I did not see Geoff Bosigo there, Chairperson.
I put it to you that Geoff Bosigo was at the bridge where Mr Nofomela was and that that's where they were waiting for the people who had gone on foot into the township.
They did not go in there per foot, they went in there with the bus, Chairperson.
After this incident - you say after this incident this matter was reported to Maj de Kock.
Why was it reported to him?
Because he is the Commander of Section C1, Chairperson.
But he never gave instructions that people should go there.
The instructions had already been given in Pretoria that we had to go to Durban and we could work in the Durban area as it suited us, Chairperson.

So you want the hearing to believe that a decision was taken to infiltrate and subsequently to take a weapon into Chesterville and after the shooting incident, only then was Maj de Kock given the information.  Is that what you want the hearing to believe?

What I want to say is the information had been conveyed to Mr de Kock after the shooting incident.  The planning from the police station before we went into Chesterville the first time and then up to the shooting, of this Mr de Kock knew nothing.  The first time that he had any knowledge was when Willie Nortje arrived at CR Swart and reported to him that a shooting had taken place in Chesterville, Mr Chairperson.
And Mr Willie Nortje was under the command of Maj de Kock.
Yes.  I put it to you that your version of the events is far from the truth.
Mr Chairperson, I was there, I have nothing to hide and this is what I want to give evidence to.

I've got no further questions, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RAMAWELE
Thank you, Mr Ramawele.  Mr Hugo, have you got any questions?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	Mr Vermeulen in saying, and you must help me if I'm wrong, you were also a State witness against Mr de Kock in his criminal trial, not so?
You testified about various charges against Mr de Kock during this trial.
And is it so that on the basis of your evidence that because of that, Mr de Kock was found guilty and he was convicted.
And therefore you applied for amnesty in respect of a whole series of offences in which you were involved during your involvement with Vlakplaas.
And so it is that during this range of offences for which you've asked for amnesty, Mr de Kock's name appears very prominently.
He was the person who gave the instructions and he was the main actor in all these operations.
And not at one stage did you hesitate or try to avoid from the fact to involve Mr de Kock in these operations and you said exactly what the part he played in these operations.

So I accept that the Attorney-General approached you when you were to give evidence against Mr de Kock in the criminal case, and that they also thoroughly questioned you regarding these activities you were involved in, to complete the charge sheet against Mr de Kock.

And I accept that you gave all the information that you had because you knew that you can obtain a 204 indemnity regarding the Criminal Procedure Act, and because of that you had to make a full disclosure.
Did you tell the Attorney-General that an offence was committed in Chesterville?
Did you tell them that they had to prosecute de Kock, because he was guilty of an offence?
And was it only because he was not involved in an offence regarding this incident?
When you came from Pretoria to Durban, you were instructed to obtain information regard who were involved in killing security policemen in Durban.
Is it correct to say that the whole Vlakplaas contingent was sent to Durban?
And to the best of your knowledge, this Vlakplaas contingent was divided into various groups, the white members were the group leaders and every group was allocated a few askaris to assist them.

And is it correct to say that Mr de Kock as the Commanding Officer of Vlakplaas, was only the co-ordinator because many of these groups were sent to the field and then they reported back to him from time to time?

Is it also correct - is it correct rather, that the groups who were sent into the field operated on their own initiative because they had to identify where the flashpoints were and to determine which information they could gather?
So Mr de Kock never told "You to go to Chesterville, there is the problem"?
And it's possible that at the same time, or at the same time when the Chesterville incident took place other groups for example, we acting in kwaMashu or in Umlazi or in Lamontville?

Then I want to put it to you that regarding Mr Radebe's version - and I want to say here right from the beginning he is a bit uncertain about this, but his version as he remembers that is that they did not first go into Chesterville, then talk to the victims and were then asked to give a weapon as a so-called showpiece.  As he recollects it, weapons were given to them right from the beginning and by that I mean 1 AK and handgrenades, that they went with these weapons into Chesterville right from the beginning.

I will not dispute that, but as far as I can remember I can remember the AK47 handed by Nortje to Radebe.  The other could be possible.  I was not there all the time when Willie Nortje informed the people.
And you addressed this aspect, but as far as you can remember there was no previous planning that people had to be killed.
Nee, onder geen omstandighede nie, Meneer.
En trouens, die feit dat daar 'n skietery plaasgevind het, het eintlik maar as 'n groot verassing en tot 'n mate 'n skok gekom.

Dit is korrek, Mnr die Voorsitter.
TYPED IN AFRIKAANS AS THERE WAS NO ENGLISH INTERPRETATION
And when you reported at the CR Swart - let me first ask you, what time did you report?
I'm not sure about the time, but I think it was late that evening, it was between 11 o'clock and 1 o'clock.
You have already testified that Mr de Kock was in the sleeping quarters, and I accept that he was woken up, what was his reaction when he was told there was a shooting incident?
Mr de Kock got up, I think he contacted the security officer, Col Andy and they went back to the scene that same night.
What I'm trying to say it, was Mr de Kock surprised, was he shocked or did it seem as if he expected that?
He was very surprised, he did not expect that.

And I see you are saying in your affidavit, which is part of the amnesty application, that Mr de Kock informed Col Andy Taylor, you suspect that he informed him because Taylor was also there.  If you mention that, does it mean after this incident?
So is it your evidence that after you'd reported back to de Kock, he and you suspect, Taylor, went back to the scene.
And at what time did that happen?
It's difficult to say, but it was early that morning, between 3 o'clock or 4 o'clock that morning.

I've got no further questions, thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR HUGO
Yes.  Thank you, Mr Hugo.  Mr Shezi?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	So Mr Vermeulen, you are saying this whole Chesterville incident was Mr Willie Nortje's initiative?

That is correct, this was not on our initiative.  As I've already said we went to the police station or the army bases, there we asked where the flashpoints were because we did not know the Durban environment very well.
You went to Chesterville Police Station in particular to find out where the Durban flashpoints were, is that what you are saying?
Why pick on Chesterville to find out about flashpoints in Durban generally?
Chesterville we found out was a flashpoint.

I'm confused now. You said you went to Chesterville to find out about flashpoints in Durban, so in other words when you went to Chesterville you did not know what was happening in Durban, you went to Chesterville to find out about flashpoints in Durban.  And my question is, why did you pick on Chesterville in particular to find out about flashpoints in Durban.

I understood that wrongly.  At that police station or army base there was a centre where all the areas in Durban were indicated on a map.  A certain army officer indicated the flashpoints on that map because we did not know what was happening in Durban and the environment, and then he indicated that Chesterville was the place which was a big flashpoint and we moved in that direction.
Your moving to Chesterville as a flashpoint, what were you going to do there, what were you hoping to achieve?
We sent the group there to see whether they could obtain information regarding the various groups and also the people responsible for the murder on the security policemen in the vicinity.
The security policemen which were killed in Durban, as you said earlier on in your evidence-in-chief, where about in Durban were they killed, was it kwaMashu, Umlazi, Claremont, where?
But you went to Chesterville hoping to find information about the Security Police which were killed.

That is correct, Mr Chairman, because Chesterville was a flashpoint and they said we should start there.  It just happened by chance that we started at Chesterville, it could have been some or other flashpoint.  The people just decided that Chesterville was the place where most activities were taking place.
It's the people we consulted at the army base at the police station and those people who indicated on the map where the flashpoints were.
Do you remember any particular person at the army base whom you contacted?
I think it was the person second-in-charge, he was a Major or a Lieutenant, I'm not sure anymore.  I can't remember his name.
At the time when you were told about flashpoints in Durban, who was present?  Was Willie Nortje present, was Mr de Kock present?
Mr de Kock was not present, Chairperson, only Nortje was there, I myself and the white members.
Mr de Kock was the Commander of the C10 Vlakplaas unit which had been requested to come to Durban to combat this killing of the Security Branch policemen, isn't it?
Yet he was not there during the briefing of what exactly the Vlakplaas C unit has asked for to come, he was not in that briefing.  Would you find that strange?  This was a very important briefing.
No, Mr Chairman, he was only - the whole unit was here as I've already testified and he had the overall command to look after everybody's interests.

What I'm saying to you is, he was the Commander of Vlakplaas C unit, the very same unit which had been asked specifically to come and combat among other things, killing of the Security Branch policemen in Durban.

And this very briefing which you are talking about, at which some Commander or some Captain at the military army base told you about flashpoints, was exactly what the C Vlakplaas unit came for in Durban and as the Commander he was not there.  Isn't it strange?
This isn't strange.  As I've already said, he was the overall person in command, he can't be on duty for 24 hours and that was why we divided into various groups and he had the overall command.

I'm not talking about being on duty 24 hours or being - for Mr de Kock to be present everywhere, I'm talking about the initial briefing, very important briefing to which the C Vlakplaas unit was summoned to come here in Durban.
And as the commander of that unit he was not there.

It was not necessary for him to be there, Mr Chairman, because there were various groups as I've already said, one could have worked in Lamontville or somewhere else, I don't know all the names, but we can't expect Mr de Kock to divide himself into two or three parts so that he could be at every information session.  We worked in various groups, that is how we operated.
So the decision to go to Chesterville in particular, how did it come about?

I've already testified, we went to the army base or the police station and on the map they indicated Chesterville as a flashpoint.  That's why we went there, for no other reason.  If they said Lamontville or wherever, we would have gone there.  Chesterville was the place indicated then, there was no specific reason why we started there.  It was a flashpoint.
The security policemen that were killed in Durban, do you know in which part of Durban were they killed?
Yet the purpose - okay, I'm not going to ask that anymore.  You have applied only for being in possession of an AK47 and not the conspiracy to murder.
Just tell this Commission, this being in possession of an AK, at what stage did you possess it and for how long, how did you come in contact with it, where and when?
The AK47 was in the vehicle we were travelling with.
You knew there was an AK47 in the vehicle?
No, not specifically when we came down from Vlakplaas.
At what stage did you know that there was an AK47 involved in this whole episode?
When Willie handed the AK47 to Mr Radebe.
You did not touch the AK47 or take it to somebody and give it to somebody?

So what exactly are you applying for in connection with this AK47?  You are not aware it was in the vehicle when you drove from Pretoria to Durban, you were are not aware at any stage, you were only became aware of it when Willie Nortje touched it and gave it to somebody?  You did not even touch the weapon, why apply for amnesty for it?
It was not necessary for me to touch the weapon, it was in the vehicle in which we were travelling and people were shot with this weapon.
Before the shooting ...(indistinct) you said you did not know that there was a weapon in the vehicle, isn't it, at any point in time?
No, Mr Chairman, not as far as I can recollect.
So you are applying for being in possession of something that you did not know that you were ever in possession of, is that what you are telling this Commission?
Afterwards I knew that there was a weapon in the car.
If Nortje had not taken the weapon from the boot you would not have known there was a weapon in the vehicle.
Then I wouldn't have known it.
Up till today you would not have known?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	The group that went, Sgt Radebe and the others, were you present at any point in time when they were given instructions to go to Chesterville?

Okay, I'll repeat that.  When the group which went to Chesterville with Sgt Radebe, as you said you first waited by the graveyard and then later by the bridge, what instructions were given to that group when that group went to Chesterville?

At the graveyard they were instructed to infiltrate, go into Chesterville.  I think they obtained an address from the police station or there where they obtained the information, they went to that address, they returned and said they met people there but the people do not trust them.
The purpose of infiltration, what was it for, was it going to infiltrate them and then what happened thereafter?
They infiltrate and they try to obtain names and addresses of activists and those types of things. - that type of information.
They had to trace these people to find out who killed the security policemen.
Now the whole infiltration was merely to find out who these people were and then hopefully in the process the information about the killing of the policemen was going to come out.
Did you hope that this information was going to come out in Chesterville in particular?
Not in Lamontville, not anywhere else?
In Lamontville, if we could information there it would have been fine, but at that stage we were not in Lamontville we were in Chesterville.

These details about the infiltration which you've just outlined, were those given to the group that ...(indistinct) such an endeavour and if so, who gave those instructions and where were you at that time?
And the larger part of my question was, where were you at that time when Willie Nortje gave those instructions?
I was with Nortje in the vehicle.
And there was no instruction, or there were no instructions for any arrest during the process or during the operation of the group that went to Chesterville?

Mr Radebe is a policeman, he had been working for Vlakplaas for a long time, it was not necessary to give him instructions.  If there was a suspect it was not necessary to tell him to arrest somebody, he knew what to do.

I didn't ask you about Sgt Radebe's ranks or knowledge or capabilities, I am saying only instructions which were given - you said earlier on they were given instructions to go and find information, find the names of the people and hopefully the information about the killers of the Security Branch policemen was going to come out, and I am saying to you, the instruction to arrest in particular, was that given or not?  Let's forget about Sgt Radebe's capabilities and his rank and everything.
No instructions were given to arrest, Mr Chairman.

And then you are saying, within that short space of time whatever that amount of time would have been of the infiltration, it was going to be able for somebody to find out who those people were, whether they were involved in the killing of the Security Branch policemen and hopefully there would be proof in that regard, is that what you are saying?

No, this is not what I said, all that was said was that the people were told to go into that area and whether that took a day, that was a very short exercise, it was a short time and the people realised that the people did not trust them, they withdrew, they came back to us, they asked for a weapon to serve as a showpiece and they returned.  I did not say they had to obtain the information within five minutes, it could have taken one day, three days or weeks.  We were allocated to the Durban area for at least one month.
You were a policeman at that time with some experience, what did you say your rank was at the time?
I was a Warrant Officer, Mr Chairman.
Investigation of murder as it were, because policemen were killed, murder had been committed, would that have been the ordinary way of trying to find information about investigations?
I don't understand what you're asking.

Is this how you investigate a murder usually, you infiltrate every area in a city?  If somebody is killed in Durban in Smith Street, then you infiltrate every single area in Durban?  This is the question.

I wouldn't say every single area has to be infiltrated, that's why we started where the flashpoint was and that was Chesterville.  If I remember correctly, there were also people deployed to Lamontville and you just follow up the information which you obtain.

Thank you, Mr Chairman, just two last questions.
	What do you mean Chesterville as flashpoint?  Just explain that to me and the Commission.
At that stage Chesterville was a flashpoint, there were a lot of problems there, there were many Self-defence Units, there were unrests in that area.

And one more question which was I believe, put earlier on to you by Mr Ramawele.  I'm going to put it to you.  The group that went to Chesterville, Sgt Radebe and others, they drove in a separate car to go and find information which was going to be used later on to make a follow-up about the killing of the Security Branch policemen, will it be correct to say that if that information was received, further investigations or other follow-ups of information received would have been done some days later, depending on the nature of the information of course?
Why were you then waiting down there by the bridge for these guys to come back?
Because we were the handlers of those people and should any problems arise, we could assist them.
I asked you for an example, give an example.

The car could have broken down, somebody could have been injured, somebody could have fallen ill or something like that, they perhaps needed additional assistance, perhaps more information about the environment.
The local policemen, Chesterville policemen, were they in any way ever contacted, were they nearby you, what was the case?
No, Mr Chairman, we did not contact them.
Did you and those guys which had went to Chesterville, carry any two-way radios by which you were communicating?  I don't think cellphones were there when you were there at that time.
Then suppose the car broke down right where they were, how would you have known about it and more specifically, how could you have got in there?
I don't know, Mr Chairman, they would have made some or other plan to get back to us.  That is all I can say, I can't speculate what we would have done had something happened.
Wouldn't they have looked for you at the graveyard?
No, they knew we moved to the bridge.
Did you tell them you were going to the bridge now?
One more question.  Did you eventually find information about the killing of the policemen?  Eventually, did you get that information?
Not as far as I know, Mr Chairman.  Before we could obtain the information shooting broke out.
Were there any other follow-ups in any other township of a similar sort of trying to get this information or the Chesterville incident was the only one by which you attempted to get this information?
I don't know, Mr Chairman.  There were other groups who went out, I don't know what they achieved.
I'm talking about your group, your group.
No, after the shooting our group went to Pretoria the next morning.
And then as far as your group is concerned, the whole purpose of trying to get information about the killing of policemen just went up in smoke?  It was never pursued anymore?
Not in Durban, no Mr Chairman.

That will be all, Mr Chairman, thank you.

	So is that all you did, is that all the group did?  You infiltrated, you sent the people into Chesterville, a shooting took place, then you packed up and you left home.

Thank you, Honourable Chairperson.

The information about Charles Ndaba, you didn't know about that at the time of this incident having taken place?

And the information about Charles Ndaba at that stage was that he was involved in the murder of policemen?

Is this from Willie yesterday only?
Okay.  Were you not present with Willie at the time of the briefing with Lt Hunter?

And that was the only source of your information at that stage, not so?

Okay.  Were you not present though with him at all times from the briefing session to the time of the incident taking place?
And there was no-one else that you can recall that he spoke to, to verify any other - any of the information that was received?

Mr Chairperson, I do not know, my memory tells me it was an AK47.  A Shay is a lot smaller, it's a handgun.

Not handed over, just showed, Mr Chairperson.

No, this is wrong Chairperson, because you cannot do this, this is definitely a mistake.  I know that Simon came to us, he asked us for an AK47 to show to the people because the people weren't very happy, they did not really trust him, Chairperson.
My Afrikaans is not so great, does "pleiding te gee", does it mean to live out the legend, to give them some kind of credibility?  Is that what is meant by "pleiding"?

What type of weapons do the askaris have?

Yes, there had been weapons that came from the police that had been issued to them and if they were finished with deployment, then of the people who were not really credible, these weapons were taken back from them and then if they go on leave, then it is taken in and if then he goes onto an operation again it is issued again.
No, these were normal police issue weapons, Chairperson.
Mr Nofomela says that it is possible that of these askaris had been given Tokarevs.
I would not be able to comment on this operation.  On other operations yes, they would have received them if they were infiltrating certain places.
I'm not sure, I cannot comment on this. I just know about the AK47, Chairperson.
Would it have been an approach if you want to infiltrate, to give your prey training with weapons, where you pretend to be MK?
This could be the case, Chairperson, this would have helped a lot if you can gain the person's confidence.
And then you would have used eastern block weapons?
You would not use a police 9mm weapon?

Thank you, Honourable Chairperson.
	I'm sorry I might have missed this, correct me if I'm wrong, but between you and Willie, neither of you handed weapons over to the group that went in to infiltrate?
Yes, we did not hand over anything else, they had their own weapons, the service pistols that they were issued with and this is what they use, Chairperson.

If they had gone in there to infiltrate with their normal service weapons, would it not have been dangerous if there was a problem that had arisen during the interaction with whoever they would have been with?  Would it not have been easier for them to go in with perhaps eastern block weapons, to carry out the legend that they were in fact members of a liberation movement?

That would the case, Chairperson, but their own service pistols are normally hidden on their person and then they can infiltrate without the people knowing about it, and this is probably why he asked for the AK47.
But you'll accept with an infiltration it's a dangerous situation, anything can happen.  They could have been ...(intervention)
... they could have been "gevisenteer" - I'm not sure what the English word is.
Searched, yes.  That possibility is in fact a real possibility, things go wrong.  So it would have been foolish of them to go in with their normal service weapons, not so?

No, this is not true, Chairperson.  Because why would they then suddenly for some strange reason want to search a person and take his clothes off?  I can't believe this, this has never happened, Chairperson.

But doesn't it make sense?  I mean you're going to go and infiltrate, you are going to pretend to be an MK member and now you are going to go in there with a police pistol.  Your chances are virtually naught
that the people would trust you, doesn't it make more sense to use eastern block weapons, Tokarevs or whatever?
This does make sense, Chairperson, but at that stage as at Chesterville, it was not planned that the thing would escalate in that manner.

Yes, that's a different point, Ms Patel would probably continue with this, but I will just return to the question that she had posed to you.  Doesn't it make more sense if you want to infiltrate to issue eastern block weapons to your members?
Yes, I agree with this completely, Mr Chairperson, it would be a lot better if everything is eastern block.

Thank you, Honourable Chairperson.
	The shooting that took place, you were in the van at the time when it occurred, not so?  Or you were under the bridge or somewhere there when it occurred.
Can you tell us what type of shooting you heard, was it just from the AK47 or was it from other weapons as well?
It was an enormous concentrated fire or firing that had taken place for, let's make it a maximum of 10 to 15 seconds I would say.
And the group that came back, did they report that they all shot?  That they all took part in the shooting?  Because there was a report.
I wouldn't be able to say this, all I can remember is that Simon had returned and said that there had been a shooting.

Well if I refer you - let me refer you to your application, page 75.  On your Chesterville incident, the second paragraph you say
"A skirmish broke out between them and the askaris came to report that they had killed people."
You don't say Simon Radebe only, you say "the askaris" and - well you amended your papers earlier on, you didn't amend this, so what is your comment?
What I mean with this is that the whole group came from wherever they had been and Simon Radebe, as the one in command of them, came to report about this.  There is nothing funny about this sentence.
Was Simon Radebe an askari at that stage?
No, he was a police officer, Chairperson.

Well then it doesn't tie in with what you stated here, you said
"Die askaris het kom rapporteer"
... not Simon, and Simon is not an askari.
The askaris worked with Simon, Chairperson.
No, but they didn't report to you, you're saying Simon reported to you.

This is correct.  The word "askaris", one uses if - this was used as a general term.  If the group was out and they returned we always refer to the group as askaris.  I could also have said "the group".  I didn't mean anything funny with this, or I didn't try to hide anything, that if one reads it like this then it means that every askari had to say look, I fired a shot and this guy fired a shot and that everyone had to come and report on their own.  I just meant that the group came and Simon said that there had been a shooting, Chairperson.
What did Simon say exactly when he got back, can you recall?

If I can remember correctly he just said that a shooting had taken place, Chairperson, and that people had been killed.  I wouldn't say that these were his exact words, but this is basically the run of what he had said.
Was there no discussion between Willie and Simon in your presence about this?
Willie could have spoken to him further, I do believe this, but I did not listen to the conversation, Chairperson.
Did Simon get into your vehicle at the bridge when you returned back to the police station?
You mean back to CR Swart?
No, he drove his own bus back to CR Swart, if my memory serves me correctly.
So when did he make a report to Willie, can you remember?

Directly after the shooting when he came from Chesterville he reported.  We waited at the bridge and he reported there to the whole group and from there they had gone to CR Swart in their own vehicle and we went with our own vehicle to CR Swart as well.

So as far as you can recall that is all he said at the scene at the bridge, that there was a skirmish, people had been shot, and then everybody departed back to CR Swart?  There must have been a discussion then or a meeting at CR Swart again, to get further details as to what had happened, not so?

This is correct, and Simon and his group went to their sleeping quarters, we went to Col de Kock and we informed him that a shooting had taken place.  What exactly had been said there I cannot remember now, it happened a long time ago, Chairperson.
Were you with Willie when the report was made to Mr de Kock?
And there wasn't another meeting with Simon before you went to Mr de Kock to give him a full report as to what had happened?
Not that I can remember, Chairperson.

So at that stage when the report was made to Mr de Kock, the only thing that could have been said to him was that you had tried to - the group had tried to infiltrate, perhaps a cell at Chesterville and that there was a shooting and people had been shot, but that was it.
This is correct, Chairperson, I think that was basically what could have been said.  I cannot remember word for word.
Well someone put it, I don't know if it was Mr Hugo, that you very quickly left that scene.
And that you left in a hurry from the scene, that you left Chesterville in a hurry.  So there hadn't been a chance?
No, we didn't really have many opportunities to talk.

Yes.  Have you still got a few things to cover?
